conclusion: Determine work done by ideal gas during cyclic process A→B→C→A using P-V diagram and temperature at state A as 200 K.
P-V diagram with Y-axis as pressure in units of 10^5 Pa and X-axis as volume in liters.
State A: (2 L, 1 x 10^5 Pa), State B: (2 L, 4 x 10^5 Pa), State C: (5 L, 1 x 10^5 Pa).
Process forms a triangle: A→B (constant volume), B→C (diagonal), C→A (constant pressure).
Net work done by gas is area enclosed by cycle on P-V diagram; for ideal gas, net work equals net heat transfer.
Work done by gas in P-V process is area under curve; sign depends on direction (expansion positive, compression negative).
Process A→B: Constant volume, work done is 0 since ΔV = 0.
Process B→C: Calculate slope of line as -1 x 10^5 Pa/L and equation of line as p = (-1 x 10^5)V + 6 x 10^5.
Process B→C: Calculate work done as 750 J using integral of pressure over volume change.
Process C→A: Constant pressure, calculate work done as -300 J since volume decreases.
Total work done in cycle: W_total = 0 + 750 + (-300) = 450 J.
Alternative method: Calculate area of triangle as 450 J to confirm work done.
Temperature at A is 200 K; use ideal gas law for verification but not necessary for work calculation.
Calculate n using ideal gas law at state A as approximately 0.12 mol.
Final answer: Work done by gas on surroundings during cyclic process is 450 J.
